awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2022 Cyber-Physical Systems Principal Investigators Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to plan and organize the 2022 National Science Foundation (NSF) Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigator (PI) Meeting. This meeting convenes all PIs of the NSF CPS Program for the 13 time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place during the Fall of 2022 in Alexandria, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agency representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-driven and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PIs, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.  This will be a hybrid PI meeting.  It will include both in-person and virtual elements.  This will be the first CPS PI meeting that includes extensive in-person attendance since the pandemic.  The virtual component of the PI meeting will also enable a larger community of researchers spanning academia, industry, and Government to also participate.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the NSF-funded CPS Principal Investigators meet to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across a broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or sponsors. The 2022 PI meeting will feature lightning talks from researchers, poster sessions, special topic workshops, demonstrations and keynotes from leaders in the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The twelfth NSF Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting aimed to manage the logistical arrangements for the event. Held on November 7-9, 2022, at the Crystal City Marriott in Arlington, Virginia, the meeting convened 245 stakeholders, including academic researchers, industry representatives, foreign government institutions, independent researchers, and government program managers involved in CPS programs. Of these attendees, 222 were Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs from over 100 U.S. colleges, universities, and research labs across 36 states and Washington D.C. Government program directors from NSF CISE Directorate, National Institutes of Health, Federal Highway Administration, and National Institute for Food and Agriculture were prominently represented. The major goal of the twelfth NSF Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting project was to coordinate the end-to-end logistical organization of the meeting. The 2022 CPS PI Meeting was held in person over two days from Tuesday, November 8, 2022 and Wednesday, November 9, 2022 (meeting days) with an arrival day on Monday, November 7, 2022 at the Crystal City Marriott located at 1700 Richmond Highway in the Crystal City Community of Arlington, Virginia, 22202.

The goal of CPS PI Meetings is to annually gather NSF-supported CPS PIs to discuss progress, challenges, and future directions across various sectors such as agriculture, climate change, energy, healthcare, and transportation. The meeting featured four keynote presentations by distinguished CPS research scientists. On day one, John Stankovic and George Pappas spoke on healthcare and safe autonomy, respectively. On day two, Necmiye Ozay discussed formal methods in CPS, while Shankar Sastry presented on human-automation teams.

CPS PIs were directly involved in key elements of the program including:

  • leading discussions in the form of five mini workshops that covered the topics of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for Healthcare; Ensuring Trustworthiness in AI-Enabled CPS; Intelligent Autonomous CPS: Design, Verification, and Certification; Socially Responsible Human CPS; and Workshop on the Future of CPS
  • giving real-time project long talks about the thrust and progress of their research via various panels.
  • showcasing their research via one sixty-seven (167) PI project posters and eleven (11) project demonstration presentations.
  • interacting and networking directly with each other, Government program managers, and other stakeholders during the numerous networking sessions scheduled on the arrival night and throughout the two-day program.
  • Engaging in the annual Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) and the Broadening Participation sessions.

 

Preparation for the meeting spanned nine-months and involved a Technical Program Committee comprising current CPS PIs from various institutions including Andrew Clark (Washington University in St. Louis), Chinwendu Enyioha (University of Central Florida), Stephanie Gil (Harvard University), and Simone Silvestri (University of Kentucky), Madhur Behr (University of Virginia), John Bradley (University of Nebraska, Lincoln), Luca Carloni (MIT), Grace Gao (Stanford University), Asimina Kiourti (The Ohio State University), Nina Mahmoudian (Purdue University), Fei Miao (University of Connecticut), Pierluigi Nuzzo (University of Southern CA), Jonathan Sprinkle (Vanderbilt), and Peng Wie (George Washington University).

 

All public artifacts, including a meeting webcast, website Urls, speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public 2019 CPS PI Meeting website which can be found at https://archive.cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg22.

All program committee pre-meeting working documents are stored on the private program committee working group site at https://archive.cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg22-pc and are only available to the program committee members.

Pre-meeting planning for this second PI Meeting took place over a nine-month calendar period in conjunction with members of the Vanderbilt ISIS CPS VO team and NSF CISE CPS PDs, and Technical Program lead from Duke University. Project tasks concluded with post-meeting archiving of content on the PI Meeting website and other administrative wrap-ups over a three-month period.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/05/2024
Modified by: Frankie D King
